title: How to Clear Out System Data on Your iPhone: 9 Methods & Tips

steps.title: Open up any of your apps.
steps.content: Open up any of your apps. Many apps store data in a cache to help them run more smoothly, but sometimes these caches can get large and take up too much space. Some apps that let you clear the cache are Spotify and TikTok. Clearing the cache won't delete your app data and can actually increase app performance as it reduces the risk of the cache files becoming corrupt and causing issues with your apps.

steps.title: Navigate to the app settings.
steps.content: Navigate to the app settings. Every app will be laid out differently, but if there is an option to clear the app cache, it will be somewhere in the settings or one of the settings submenus. You may need to go into a specific submenu, such as Storage or similar, to find the option to clear the app cache. Not every app will have the option to clear the cache.

steps.title: Close all of your open apps.
steps.content: Close all of your open apps. A Reddit user on the iPhone subreddit detailed a method to clear out system data. The user states that this works best when your system data is 25GB or higher. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Set your text messages to stay forever.
steps.content: Set your text messages to stay forever. You can skip this step if you don't mind losing your text messages. Navigate to Settings > Messages, then scroll down to Message History and tap on Keep Messages . Select the Forever setting.

steps.title: Turn off Wi-Fi and Bluetooth and set your phone on airplane mode.
steps.content: Turn off Wi-Fi and Bluetooth and set your phone on airplane mode. You can do this most easily by swiping down from the upper-right corner to expand the control center. Simply tap the Wi-Fi and Bluetooth buttons in the upper-left corner to turn them off, then tap the airplane button to turn on airplane mode.

steps.title: Go to Settings.
steps.content: Go to Settings .

steps.title: Tap on General.
steps.content: Tap on General .

steps.title: Select Date & Time.
steps.content: Select Date & Time .

steps.title: Toggle off Set Automatically.
steps.content: Toggle off Set Automatically. If this is not toggled on, you can skip this step.

steps.title: Tap the date and set the year to one year in the future.
steps.content: Tap the date and set the year to one year in the future.

steps.title: Keep the phone awake for 60 seconds and check your iPhone storage.
steps.content: Keep the phone awake for 60 seconds and check your iPhone storage. You should notice your system data being much lower. If not, close the Settings app before checking your storage again.

steps.title: Change the date to 3 months in the future from today's date.
steps.content: Change the date to 3 months in the future from today's date. This is nine months in the past from the date you just set. For example, if you were attempting this on July 18th, 2023, you would first change the date to July 18th, 2024, and then to October 18th, 2023.

steps.title: Keep the phone awake for 60 seconds and recheck your storage.
steps.content: Keep the phone awake for 60 seconds and recheck your storage. System data should be the same as a moment ago or slightly lower.

steps.title: Return to Date & Time.
steps.content: Return to Date & Time .

steps.title: Toggle on Set Automatically.
steps.content: Toggle on Set Automatically.

steps.title: Turn off airplane mode and reenable Wi-Fi and Bluetooth.
steps.content: Turn off airplane mode and reenable Wi-Fi and Bluetooth.

steps.title: Press and hold the lock and volume up buttons.
steps.content: Press and hold the lock and volume up buttons. This will bring you to your iPhone's shut-down screen. Restarting your phone can clear out some temporary resources and give back some space from system data.

steps.title: Swipe right on the "slide to power off" slider.
steps.content: Swipe right on the "slide to power off" slider. This will turn your phone off. Wait for a few minutes before turning it back on.

steps.title: Press the power button for about 3 seconds.
steps.content: Press the power button for about 3 seconds. You should see the Apple logo as your phone powers on.

steps.title: Locate Discord and/or Instagram.
steps.content: Locate Discord and/or Instagram. Reddit users have found that Discord and Instagram both store a lot of data that is considered system data, and deleting and reinstalling these apps has been found to help reduce system data.

steps.title: Tap and hold the app until it starts to shake.
steps.content: Tap and hold the app until it starts to shake. A menu will pop up.

steps.title: Select Remove App.
steps.content: Select Remove App . If the app is not on your home screen, you will instead want to select Delete App .

steps.title: Select Delete App.
steps.content: Select Delete App . If you select Remove from Home Screen the app won't be deleted, it just won't be visible on your home screen anymore. If the app isn't on your home screen, select Delete on the pop-up.

steps.title: Go to the App Store and reinstall Discord and Instagram.
steps.content: Go to the App Store and reinstall Discord and Instagram. You'll need to sign back into your account after deleting these apps, but you should notice your system data is much lower after reinstalling.

steps.title: Open Settings.
steps.content: Open Settings . Clearing your mobile browsing history can help reduce system data, especially if you haven't cleared your browsing history in a long time or ever. Safari is the default web browser for your iPhone, and if you're using an alternative browser the setting to clear browsing history may have to be cleared via the app.

steps.title: Scroll down and select Safari.
steps.content: Scroll down and select Safari .

steps.title: Scroll down and select Clear History and Website Data.
steps.content: Scroll down and select Clear History and Website Data . Tap Clear History and Data in the pop-up to finish clearing out your browsing data. [2] X Research source This will also delete browser cookies, which will sign you out of any sites you've been signed in to and remove saved usernames and passwords.

steps.title: Open Settings.
steps.content: Open Settings . Removing large message attachments no longer needed can help free up some of your system data.

steps.title: Tap General.
steps.content: Tap General .

steps.title: Tap iPhone Storage.
steps.content: Tap iPhone Storage .

steps.title: Select Messages.
steps.content: Select Messages .

steps.title: Tap Review Large Attachments.
steps.content: Tap Review Large Attachments . All of your message attachments will appear in this menu, sorted from largest to smallest.

steps.title: Click Edit in the upper-right corner.
steps.content: Click Edit in the upper-right corner. This will allow you to select the attachments you want to delete.

steps.title: Select attachments for deletion and tap the trash can icon.
steps.content: Select attachments for deletion and tap the trash can icon. This will delete the selected attachments to free up some space on your phone.

steps.title: Open any app that allows you to download offline content.
steps.content: Open any app that allows you to download offline content. Some examples are Spotify and Netflix, which let you download content to use when you're offline.

steps.title: Delete the stored offline content.
steps.content: Delete the stored offline content. How to do this varies per app, but you should be able to find the correct setting within the app's settings menu. It may be under a submenu such as Storage .

steps.title: Open Settings.
steps.content: Open Settings . Some users have noticed that updating your phone can help reduce system data. If your phone is due for an update, try updating it to see if that fixes the issue. If you don't have enough space on your phone to install the update, this method will not work for you.

steps.title: Select General.
steps.content: Select General .

steps.title: Tap Software Update.
steps.content: Tap Software Update . If there is a software update, it will appear here.

steps.title: Select Download and Install.
steps.content: Select Download and Install . Allow your phone to download and install the update, which may take some time. Your phone will restart once the update is complete. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Open Settings.
steps.content: Open Settings . If nothing else works, restoring your iPhone is a surefire way to clear out your old system data, but it is a drastic step. Before restoring your phone, ensure you have created a backup .

steps.title: Tap General.
steps.content: Tap General .

steps.title: Select Transfer or Reset iPhone.
steps.content: Select Transfer or Reset iPhone . It's at the bottom of the screen, so you'll have to scroll to see the option.

steps.title: Select Erase All Content and Settings.
steps.content: Select Erase All Content and Settings . You will be prompted to enter your passcode or your Apple ID password. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Allow the phone to reset.
steps.content: Allow the phone to reset. This will take some time.

steps.title: Set up your phone once it has been reset.
steps.content: Set up your phone once it has been reset. You can restore your phone from a backup during the initial setup process.
